default.prompt: What is 'Code Signing' in mobile development?
options: A way to encrypt the source code
A security process that uses digital signatures to verify the app's author and ensure the code hasn't been altered
Writing code that only works on one device
Naming your variables with specific prefixes
default.explanation: Both Apple and Google require apps to be signed with a private key/certificate. Without it, the device will refuse to install the app for security reasons.
default.interviewTip: On iOS, this involves 'Provisioning Profiles'; on Android, it involves an 'Upload Key' (Keystore).

options: A hardware update for the phone
Updating the JavaScript bundle of the app directly without going through the App Store review process
An update that only works via Wi-Fi
A way to change the app's price remotely
default.explanation: Since React Native apps execute a JS bundle, you can push a new bundle to a cloud service (like EAS Update or CodePush), and the app will download it on the next launch.
default.interviewTip: OTA updates are great for bug fixes but cannot be used to update native code (like adding a new library that requires `npx expo prebuild`).

options: A high-speed internet connection
An open-source automation tool that handles tasks like generating screenshots and submitting apps to stores
A way to make the app run faster
A library for fast scrolling
default.explanation: Fastlane automates the tedious parts of the release process, such as incrementing build numbers, signing binaries, and uploading to TestFlight.
default.interviewTip: Fastlane is the industry standard for mobile CI/CD pipelines.

options: A new version of JavaScript
A cloud-based ecosystem for building, submitting, and updating Expo and React Native apps
An analytics tool for tracking user clicks
A database for storing app data
default.explanation: EAS Build allows you to compile your Android (AAB) and iOS (IPA) binaries on Expo's servers, removing the need for local Xcode/Android Studio setups.
default.interviewTip: EAS works even for 'bare' React Native projects, not just managed Expo ones.

default.prompt: What is the difference between an .APK and an .AAB file on Android?
options: .APK is for testing; .AAB (Android App Bundle) is the modern format for store submission that optimizes download size
.AAB is only for older phones
There is no difference
.APK is an Apple file
default.explanation: Google Play uses the .AAB to generate optimized .APKs for each specific device configuration (e.g., only including the images for that screen's density).
default.interviewTip: Google Play now mandates the use of .AAB for all new app submissions.

options: A game about flying planes
Apple's official platform for distributing beta versions of apps to testers
A tool for testing network speed
A performance monitoring tool
default.explanation: TestFlight allows you to invite up to 10,000 testers to try your app before it goes live on the App Store.
default.interviewTip: Android's equivalent is called 'Google Play Internal/Closed Testing'.

default.prompt: What happens if you change a native library and then try to push an OTA update to old versions of the app?
options: The app updates perfectly
The app will likely crash or malfunction because the JS code expects a native module that isn't there
The OS blocks the update
The app bundle becomes too large
default.explanation: OTA updates must be compatible with the 'native runtime' of the installed app. If the runtime changes, you must submit a full store update.
default.interviewTip: Use 'Runtime Versions' in EAS to ensure updates only reach compatible app versions.

default.prompt: What is a 'Keystore' file in Android development?
options: A file that stores all the app's data
A binary file that contains the private keys used to sign your app
A list of all store names in the app
A configuration file for Gradle
default.explanation: If you lose your production Keystore, you will not be able to update your app on the Play Store ever again (unless you have Google Play App Signing enabled).
default.interviewTip: Always back up your Keystore securely and never commit it to public version control.

default.prompt: In CI/CD, what is the 'Build' phase?
options: Writing the code
The process of compiling source code into an executable binary (IPA or APK/AAB)
Designing the UI
Reviewing the app by the store team
default.explanation: On a CI server (like GitHub Actions), this phase involves installing dependencies, running native build scripts (Gradle/xcodebuild), and signing the output.
default.interviewTip: Mobile builds are 'heavy' and often take 10-30 minutes, so caching dependencies is crucial.

default.prompt: What are 'Environmental Variables' (.env) used for in deployment?
options: To save memory
To store sensitive information like API keys or backend URLs that change between Staging and Production
To define the app's font
To track the device's location
default.explanation: You don't want to hardcode your 'Development' API URL into your 'Production' build. Environment variables allow you to swap these at build time.
default.interviewTip: In React Native, libraries like 'react-native-config' or 'expo-constants' are used to access these.

default.prompt: What is 'Semantic Versioning' (SemVer) in the context of mobile releases?
options: A way to name components
A versioning system (Major.Minor.Patch) that helps communicate the significance of an update
A tool for translating code
The order of build steps
default.explanation: Major = Breaking changes, Minor = New features, Patch = Bug fixes.
default.interviewTip: For mobile, remember that 'Build Number' (iOS) and 'Version Code' (Android) must also increment for every store submission.

options: Users giving your app a 5-star rating
The manual and automated process where Apple/Google check your app against their policies before letting it go live
Reviewing the code with your teammates
Checking the app's performance
default.explanation: Apple is famous for a strict review process that checks for design, security, and content. Google's process is faster but has become stricter recently.
default.interviewTip: Always provide a demo account to the reviewers if your app requires a login.

default.prompt: What is the purpose of 'App Center' (by Microsoft)?
options: To build a website for the app
A CI/CD and crash reporting service specifically for mobile apps
A way to download apps on Windows
A tool for managing app icons
default.explanation: It provides cloud builds, distribution to testers, and analytics/crash reporting (though many features are being moved to Azure).
default.interviewTip: Many teams use App Center for its simplicity in managing build pipelines.

options: A person who wants to release an app
A version of the app that is potentially ready for production unless serious bugs are found
The final version of the code
A tool for deleting old builds
default.explanation: An RC is typically shared with stakeholders or a internal QA team for one final 'smoke test' before going to the public.
default.interviewTip: Testing the RC on real devices is the final safety net.

default.prompt: What is 'Sentry' or 'Bugsnag' used for in production?
options: To protect the app from viruses
To track and report JavaScript and Native crashes from real users
To speed up the app
To monitor the internet connection
default.explanation: When a user's app crashes, these tools capture the 'Stack Trace', helping you find and fix the exact line of code that failed.
default.interviewTip: You must upload 'Source Maps' to these services so the cryptic, minified production code can be turned back into readable code for debugging.

options: Releasing the app on a stage
Releasing an update to a small percentage of users (e.g., 5%) and slowly increasing it if no bugs are reported
A way to release the app screen-by-screen
Releasing the app for free first
default.explanation: This mitigates risk. If a major bug exists, it only affects 5% of users instead of 100%, and you can pause the rollout to fix it.
default.interviewTip: Both the Play Store and App Store support this natively.

default.prompt: How do you handle 'Secrets' (like private keys) in a CI/CD environment?
options: By committing them to the repository
By using 'Secret Variables' provided by the CI platform (e.g., GitHub Secrets)
By emailing them to the server
By typing them into the terminal manually every time
default.explanation: Secrets are injected into the build environment at runtime, so they never appear in the source code or logs.
default.interviewTip: Never, under any circumstances, commit a .keystore or a .p8 file to a public git repo.
